an9.41:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṃ nāma mallānaṃ nigamo.
an9.41:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.

an9.41:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya uruvelakappaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
an9.41:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Uruvelakappa for alms.

an9.41:1.3.pli: Uruvelakappe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
an9.41:1.3.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

an9.41:1.4.pli: “idheva tāva tvaṃ, ānanda, hohi, yāvāhaṃ mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhāmi divāvihārāyā”ti.
an9.41:1.4.eng: “Ānanda, you stay right here, while I plunge deep into the Great Wood for the day’s meditation.”

an9.41:1.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

an9.41:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
an9.41:1.6.eng: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Great Wood and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

an9.41:2.1.pli: Atha kho tapusso gahapati yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho tapusso gahapati āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an9.41:2.1.eng: The householder Tapussa went up to Venerable Ānanda, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an9.41:3.1.pli: “Mayaṃ, bhante ānanda, gihī kāmabhogino kāmārāmā kāmaratā kāmasammuditā.
an9.41:3.1.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, we are laypeople who enjoy sensual pleasures. We like sensual pleasures, we love them and take joy in them.

an9.41:3.2.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ gihīnaṃ kāmabhogīnaṃ kāmārāmānaṃ kāmaratānaṃ kāmasammuditānaṃ papāto viya khāyati, yadidaṃ nekkhammaṃ.
an9.41:3.2.eng: But renunciation seems like an abyss.

an9.41:3.3.pli: Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, ‘imasmiṃ dhammavinaye daharānaṃ daharānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:3.3.eng: I have heard that in this teaching and training there are very young mendicants whose minds leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in renunciation. They see it as peaceful.

an9.41:3.4.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye bhikkhūnaṃ bahunā janena visabhāgo, yadidaṃ nekkhamman”ti.
an9.41:3.4.eng: Renunciation is the dividing line between the multitude and the mendicants in this teaching and training.”

an9.41:4.1.pli: “Atthi kho etaṃ, gahapati, kathāpābhataṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
an9.41:4.1.eng: “Householder, we should see the Buddha about this matter.

an9.41:4.2.pli: Āyāma, gahapati, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocessāma.
an9.41:4.2.eng: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.

an9.41:4.3.pli: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā”ti.
an9.41:4.3.eng: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

an9.41:5.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho tapusso gahapati āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.

an9.41:5.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tapussena gahapatinā saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an9.41:5.2.eng: Then Ānanda together with Tapussa went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Ānanda told him what had happened.

an9.41:6.2.pli: ‘mayaṃ, bhante ānanda, gihī kāmabhogino kāmārāmā kāmaratā kāmasammuditā, tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ gihīnaṃ kāmabhogīnaṃ kāmārāmānaṃ kāmaratānaṃ kāmasammuditānaṃ papāto viya khāyati, yadidaṃ nekkhammaṃ’.

an9.41:6.3.pli: Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, ‘imasmiṃ dhammavinaye daharānaṃ daharānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.

an9.41:6.4.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye bhikkhūnaṃ bahunā janena visabhāgo yadidaṃ nekkhamman’”ti.

an9.41:7.1.eng: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!

an9.41:7.2.pli: Mayhampi kho, ānanda, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
an9.41:7.2.eng: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought,

an9.41:7.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, nekkhamme cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:7.4.eng: But my mind did not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in renunciation. I didn’t see it as peaceful.

an9.41:7.6.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me nekkhamme cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’?
an9.41:7.6.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in renunciation? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’

an9.41:7.8.pli: ‘kāmesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, nekkhamme ca ānisaṃso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
an9.41:7.8.eng: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of renunciation, and so I haven’t developed that.

an9.41:7.9.pli: Tasmā me nekkhamme cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:7.9.eng: That’s why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in renunciation. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:7.11.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ kāmesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulaṃ kareyyaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṃ,
an9.41:7.11.eng: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of renunciation, I were to develop that.

an9.41:7.12.pli: ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:7.12.eng: It’s possible that my mind would leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in renunciation. And I would see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:7.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, aparena samayena kāmesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulamakāsiṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseviṃ.
an9.41:7.13.eng: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of sensual pleasures and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of renunciation and developed that.

an9.41:7.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:7.14.eng: Then my mind leapt forth, gained confidence, settled down, and became decided in renunciation. I saw it as peaceful.

an9.41:7.15.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an9.41:7.15.eng: And so, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.41:7.16.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:7.16.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:7.17.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.41:7.17.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.41:7.18.pli: evamevassa me kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:7.18.eng: In the same way, when perception and focus accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me, that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:8.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.41:8.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled … enter and remain in the second absorption?’

an9.41:8.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, avitakke cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:8.3.eng: But my mind did not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in not placing the mind. I didn’t see it as peaceful.

an9.41:8.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me avitakke cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’?
an9.41:8.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in not placing the mind? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’

an9.41:8.7.pli: ‘vitakkesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, avitakke ca ānisaṃso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
an9.41:8.7.eng: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of placing the mind, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of not placing the mind, and so I haven’t developed that.

an9.41:8.8.pli: Tasmā me avitakke cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:8.8.eng: That’s why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in not placing the mind. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:8.10.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ vitakkesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulaṃ kareyyaṃ, avitakke ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṃ, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me avitakke cittaṃ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:8.10.eng: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of placing the mind, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of not placing the mind, I were to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in not placing the mind. And I would see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:8.11.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, aparena samayena vitakkesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulamakāsiṃ, avitakke ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseviṃ.
an9.41:8.11.eng: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of placing the mind and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of not placing the mind and developed that.

an9.41:8.12.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, avitakke cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:8.12.eng: Then my mind did leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in not placing the mind. I saw it as peaceful.

an9.41:8.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an9.41:8.13.eng: And so, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled … I entered and remained in the second absorption.

an9.41:8.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:8.14.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by placing the mind beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:8.15.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.41:8.15.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.41:8.16.pli: evamevassa me vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:8.16.eng: In the same way, when perception and focus accompanied by placing the mind and keeping it connected beset me, that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:9.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihareyyaṃ sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeyyaṃ yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti—upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.41:9.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, with the fading away of rapture, enter and remain in the third absorption, where I will meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss”?’

an9.41:9.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, nippītike cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:9.3.eng: But my mind did not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in freedom from rapture. I didn’t see it as peaceful.

an9.41:9.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me nippītike cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’?
an9.41:9.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in freedom from rapture? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’

an9.41:9.7.pli: ‘pītiyā kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, nippītike ca ānisaṃso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
an9.41:9.7.eng: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of rapture, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of freedom from rapture, and so I haven’t developed that.

an9.41:9.8.pli: Tasmā me nippītike cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:9.8.eng: That’s why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in freedom from rapture. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:9.10.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ pītiyā ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulaṃ kareyyaṃ, nippītike ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṃ, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me nippītike cittaṃ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:9.10.eng: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of rapture, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of freedom from rapture, I were to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being free from rapture. And I would see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:9.11.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, aparena samayena pītiyā ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulamakāsiṃ, nippītike ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseviṃ.
an9.41:9.11.eng: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of rapture and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of freedom from rapture and developed that.

an9.41:9.12.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, nippītike cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:9.12.eng: Then my mind leapt forth, gained confidence, settled down, and became decided in freedom from rapture. I saw it as peaceful.

an9.41:9.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an9.41:9.13.eng: And so, with the fading away of rapture … I entered and remained in the third absorption.

an9.41:9.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:9.14.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by rapture beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:9.15.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.41:9.15.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.41:9.16.pli: evamevassa me pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:9.16.eng: In the same way, when perception and focus accompanied by rapture beset me, that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:10.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.41:10.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness?’

an9.41:10.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:10.3.eng: But my mind did not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being without pleasure and pain. I didn’t see it as peaceful.

an9.41:10.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me adukkhamasukhe cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’?
an9.41:10.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being without pleasure and pain? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’

an9.41:10.7.pli: ‘upekkhāsukhe kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, adukkhamasukhe ca ānisaṃso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
an9.41:10.7.eng: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of being without pleasure and pain, and so I haven’t developed that.

an9.41:10.8.pli: Tasmā me adukkhamasukhe cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:10.8.eng: That’s why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being without pleasure and pain. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:10.10.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulaṃ kareyyaṃ, adukkhamasukhe ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṃ, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me adukkhamasukhe cittaṃ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:10.10.eng: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of being without pleasure and pain, I were to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being without pleasure and pain. And I would see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:10.11.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, aparena samayena upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulamakāsiṃ adukkhamasukhe ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseviṃ.
an9.41:10.11.eng: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of being without pleasure and pain and developed that.

an9.41:10.12.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:10.12.eng: Then my mind did leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in being without pleasure and pain. I saw it as peaceful.

an9.41:10.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an9.41:10.13.eng: And so, giving up pleasure and pain … I entered and remained in the fourth absorption.

an9.41:10.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:10.14.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by bliss with equanimity beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:10.15.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.41:10.15.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.41:10.16.pli: evamevassa me upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:10.16.eng: In the same way, when perception and focus accompanied by bliss with equanimity beset me, that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:11.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā “ananto ākāso”ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
an9.41:11.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space?’

an9.41:11.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato.
an9.41:11.3.eng: But my mind did not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in the dimension of infinite space. I didn’t see it as peaceful.

an9.41:11.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’?
an9.41:11.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in the dimension of infinite space? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’

an9.41:11.7.pli: ‘rūpesu kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca abahulīkato, ākāsānañcāyatane ca ānisaṃso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito.
an9.41:11.7.eng: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of forms, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of the dimension of infinite space, and so I haven’t developed that.

an9.41:11.8.pli: Tasmā me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:11.8.eng: That’s why my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in the dimension of infinite space. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:11.10.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ rūpesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulaṃ kareyyaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatane ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṃ, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṃ santanti passato’.
an9.41:11.10.eng: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of forms, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of the dimension of infinite space, I were to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided in the dimension of infinite space. And I would see it as peaceful.’

an9.41:11.11.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, aparena samayena rūpesu ādīnavaṃ disvā taṃ bahulamakāsiṃ, ākāsānañcāyatane ānisaṃsaṃ adhigamma tamāseviṃ.
an9.41:11.11.eng: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of forms and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of the dimension of infinite space and developed that.

an9.41:11.12.eng: Then my mind leapt forth, gained confidence, settled down, and became decided in the dimension of infinite space. I saw it as peaceful.

an9.41:11.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, ānanda, sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an9.41:11.13.eng: And so, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, I entered and remained in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.41:11.14.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, ānanda, iminā vihārena viharato rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:11.14.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by forms beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:11.15.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.41:11.15.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.41:11.16.pli: evamevassa me rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa me hoti ābādho.
an9.41:11.16.eng: In the same way, when perception and focus accompanied by forms beset me, that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:15.13.eng: And so, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, I entered and remained in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, my defilements were ended.

an9.41:16.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, ānanda, imā nava anupubbavihārasamāpattiyo na evaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ samāpajjimpi vuṭṭhahimpi, neva tāvāhaṃ, ānanda, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an9.41:16.1.eng: As long as I hadn’t entered into and withdrawn from these nine progressive meditative attainments in both forward and reverse order, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an9.41:16.2.pli: Yato ca kho ahaṃ, ānanda, imā nava anupubbavihārasamāpattiyo evaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ samāpajjimpi vuṭṭhahimpi, athāhaṃ, ānanda, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an9.41:16.2.eng: But when I had entered into and withdrawn from these nine progressive meditative attainments in both forward and reverse order, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an9.41:16.3.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

an9.41:16.4.pli: ‘akuppā me cetovimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
an9.41:16.4.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
